content.description: A baseball enthusiast carried out a simple linear regression to investigate whether there is a linear relationship between the number of runs scored by a player and the number of times the player was intentionally walked. Computer output from the regression analysis is shown.
content.question: Variable DF Estimate SE Intercept 1 16 2.073 Intentional Walks 1 0.50 0.037 <math alttext="R s q equals 0.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R-sq</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="beta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> represent the slope of the population regression line used to predict the number of runs scored from the number of intentional walks in the population of baseball players. A <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a slope of a regression line was conducted for the following hypotheses. <math alttext="H sub 0: beta sub 1 equals 0. H sub a: beta sub 1 is not equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>What is the appropriate test statistic for the test?

choices.label: <math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 16 over 2.073" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.073</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 16 over 0.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 16 over 0.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.50</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 0.50 over 0.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.50</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 0.50 over 0.037" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.50</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.037</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="lowercase t equals the fraction 0.50 over 0.037" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.50</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.037</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 9.5: Carrying Out a Test for the Slope of a Regression Model

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Calculate a test statistic and find a p-value, provided conditions for inference are met.
